ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom classes, asynchronous days, connect textbook homework, bulb homework assignments, discussion groups
The class met synchronously Monday, Wednesday, Friday live on Zoom. There were asynchronous assignments on Tuesday and Thursday that replaced live lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Introductory German vocabulary and grammar (i.e. word order; conjugating verbs; articles; nominative, accusative, and dative cases; etc.).
Learned vocabulary and grammar basics of German

I developed basic speaking, reading, writing, and listening skills in German. I also learned about German culture through introductory film and reading. Aside from this knowledge, I developed higher-level thinking skills that allowed me to more easily learn a foreign language. I also learned how to communicate clearly and participate in discussion, even when I was starting to learn the language in the first several weeks and I was unsure of where to begin.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I had a great instructor who was very engaging and helpful during and after class. The classes where we met face to face over Zoom were the best part of the course as you really forced to comprehend and speak German, which helped with learning. The weakness was definitely the online homework and asynchronous classwork, which oftentimes took a lot of time, mostly due to technical issues.
Professor Wilhelm is fantastic. He explains clearly, is always available to help students, is empathetic, and simultaneously makes sure the class is challenging and useful.

The strengths of this course was that it involved active participation from each student. It was the course with smallest number of students that I took this semester, which added to the course being especially engaging. 
Sometimes the directions and deadlines for certain outside-of-class assignments were not communicated as clearly as I would have liked them to be.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Anytime where we were able to engage with someone face to face was really helpful (i.e. synchronous days, weekly graduate student discussions), because it was nice to be able to practice speaking and hearing the language. The asynchronous instructional videos were very informational; however, sometimes the digital assignments were a bit finicky.
Professor Wilhelm did a fantastic job using the technology available. It was nice to have a balance between asynchronous days and Zoom classes, and the teacher always used class time efficiently.

The live virtual lectures three times per week were very successful. I feel as if my learning greatly improved because of the active participation that these live classes encouraged. The Zoom video-conferencing software was definitely different from in-person lecture, but I felt as if it didn't hinder my learning or participation at all. The asynchronous assignments that were assigned in place of these lectures twice weekly were also successful. However, there was more uncertainty to completing them, because some took much longer than the allocated 50 minutes. The virtual engagement during the live Zoom lectures was high.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would. German is a very interesting language and the instructors are all very helpful and supportive.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is a very engaging course with an average workload and intellectual challenge for a Yale College course. It is an excellent introductory foreign language class, as it is geared in every way towards the teaching and learning of basic language skills, while also developing higher-level thinking skills and creativity, such as for the projects that were assigned. The concepts in the class were clearly explained by the instructor, there was always time to ask questions, and the assignments outside of class were both engaging and very helpful to my overall learning in the course.
